questionList.questionText: A 68-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to palpitations accompanied by mild dizziness and sweating.  The symptoms started abruptly 30 minutes ago.  He has had no chest pain or shortness of breath.  Medical history is significant for hypertension and a myocardial infarction 6 months ago.  The patient is an ex-smoker with a 30-pack-year history.  Blood pressure is 102/65 mm Hg and pulse is 160/min and regular.  Oxygen saturation is 98% on 2 L nasal cannula oxygen.  On physical examination, prominent, high-amplitude jugular venous pulsations are seen intermittently at irregular intervals.  ECG reveals a regular, wide-complex tachycardia.  Which of the following best explains the patient's physical findings?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient with palpitations has a history of ischemic heart disease (ie, myocardial infarction), placing him at increased risk for ventricular arrhythmia; his ECG reveals a regular, wide-complex tachycardia consistent with ventricular tachycardia.  Cardiac arrhythmias often alter the waveform of jugular venous pulsation (JVP), which is representative of the hemodynamic changes in the right atrium throughout the cardiac cycle.  Normal JVP consists of 3 waves that correspond to increases in right atrial pressure:

  • A wave caused by right atrial contraction, closely followed by tricuspid valve closure

  • C wave caused by right ventricular contraction against a closed tricuspid valve

  • V wave, representing the peak of right atrial filling, just prior to reopening of the tricuspid valve

Cannon A waves, as seen in this patient, are intermittent, prominent A waves caused by the surge in jugular venous pressure that occurs due when the atria and ventricles happen to contract simultaneously; these waves can be seen with any arrhythmia involving atrioventricular dissociation, such as ventricular tachycardia, which is characterized by self-propagation within the ventricles without communication with the atria and is likely in this patient with recent myocardial infarction.

Other arrhythmias in which cannon A waves are commonly seen include complete atrioventricular block and frequent premature ventricular contractions.  Patients may sometimes report symptoms associated with cannon A waves, including headache, jaw pain, and sensation of neck pulsation.

(Choice A)  Left-sided valvular disease (eg, aortic regurgitation) does not typically affect the shape of the JVP waveform; however, severe disease can lead to decompensated heart failure and an increase in baseline jugular venous pressure (the entire waveform is shifted upward).

(Choice B)  Atrial fibrillation causes an absent A wave on the JVP waveform because there is no organized atrial contraction.  ECG would show an irregularly irregular rhythm.

(Choice D)  Pericardial effusion may lead to cardiac tamponade (eg, hypotension, dilated neck veins, muffled heart sounds), which can cause a flattened y descent due to external right ventricular compression with restricted diastolic filling.

(Choice E)  Tricuspid regurgitation causes a prominent V wave and absent x descent due to elevation of right atrial pressure throughout ventricular systole.

Educational objective:
The jugular venous pulsation waveform is representative of right atrial hemodynamics throughout the cardiac cycle.  Cannon A waves are intermittent, prominent A waves caused by the surge in jugular venous pressure that occurs due to right atrial contraction against a closed tricuspid valve.  These waves are indicative of a cardiac arrhythmia involving atrioventricular dissociation (eg, ventricular tachycardia, complete atrioventricular block).
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Ventricular tachycardia

questionList.questionText: A 45-year-old man comes to the office after experiencing left-sided chest pain for a day.  The pain is nonradiating and constant and increases with movement of the left hand.  The patient has had no nausea, dyspnea, diaphoresis, lightheadedness, or syncope.  He has a 25-pack-year smoking history.  Vital signs are within normal limits.  On examination, the pain is reproduced with palpation of the left-sided chest wall muscles.  ECG reveals no significant ST-segment or T-wave abnormalities.  The rhythm strip is shown in the exhibit.  Which of the following is the best approach to this patient's ECG findings?
questionList.explanationText:
Atrioventricular block

Clinical presentation

ECG features

Management

First degree

Asymptomatic

PR interval prolongation

Observation

Mobitz type I second degree

Usually asymptomatic

Progressive PR interval lengthening followed by dropped QRS complex

Observation (rarely PPM placement)

Mobitz type II second degree

Fatigue, light-headedness, syncope

Constant PR interval with randomly dropped QRS complexes

PPM placement

Third degree (complete)

Fatigue, light-headedness, syncope

Complete dissociation of P waves & QRS complexes

PPM placement

PPM = permanent pacemaker.

This patient has chest pain that is most likely musculoskeletal in nature (eg, pain worse with arm movement, chest wall tender to palpation) rather than due to myocardial ischemia.  ECG reveals normal sinus rhythm with no ischemic ST-segment or T-wave abnormalities, and an incidental finding of a prolonged PR interval (ie, >200 ms), consistent with first-degree atrioventricular (AV) block.

ECG of first-degree AV block shows a QRS complex following every P wave, but the distance between the start of the P wave and the start of the QRS complex is longer than normal.  This usually results from delayed conduction within the AV node, and affected patients are almost always asymptomatic.  Causes include AV node structural variations, enhanced vagal tone (eg, highly trained athletes), and pharmacologic AV nodal blockade (eg, beta blockers).  It can also occur in the setting of inferior wall myocardial ischemia and can rarely occur due to Lyme disease or infiltrative conduction disease (eg, sarcoidosis).

In the absence of active myocardial ischemia or overt findings of systemic disease (eg, history of rash to suggest Lyme disease, cough and dyspnea to suggest sarcoidosis), first-degree AV block is a benign finding, and observation is most appropriate.

(Choice A)  24-hour ECG monitoring (Holter monitoring) is used in patients with symptoms (eg, lightheadedness, syncope) suspected to be due to intermittent arrhythmia (eg, advanced AV block, paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia); it is not indicated in asymptomatic patients.

(Choice B)  An electrophysiology study is indicated to identify the source of some supraventricular tachycardias (eg, atrial fibrillation, atrial flutter).  It may sometimes be used to identify the level of blockade (eg, AV node vs His bundle) for advanced AV block, but it plays no role in the evaluation of first-degree AV block.

(Choice D)  Placement of a permanent pacemaker is typically indicated for advanced AV block (ie, Mobitz type II second-degree AV block, third-degree AV block); it is almost never indicated for first-degree AV block.

(Choice E)  Vagal maneuvers slow AV nodal conduction but have no effect on His bundle conduction; therefore, they may sometimes be helpful in determining the level of block in advanced AV block.  However, they are of limited use for first-degree AV block.

Educational objective:
First-degree atrioventricular (AV) block results from delayed conduction through the AV node and is recognized on ECG by a prolonged PR interval (ie, >200 ms) with a QRS complex following each P wave.  It is a benign finding and usually requires observation only.

questionList.title: Heart block

questionList.questionText:
A 57-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found confused and agitated in a park.  Medical records indicate that he has a history of schizophrenia, alcohol use disorder, and liver cirrhosis.  The patient states that he has not been taking his medications "because they never help."  Temperature is 37.2 C (99 F), blood pressure is 160/80 mm Hg, pulse is 118/min, and respirations are 24/min.  On examination, the patient is disheveled and disoriented, claiming that FBI agents have been chasing him.  His breath smells of alcohol.  Pupils are equal and reactive, and the neck is supple.  The abdomen is distended but nontender.  The skin and mucous membranes are dry.  There is mild edema in both lower extremities but no deformity.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Serum chemistry
Sodium128 mEq/L
Potassium4.0 mEq/L
Chloride88 mEq/L
Bicarbonate20 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen26 mg/dL
Creatinine2.0 mg/dL
Glucose60 mg/dL
Ammonia110 µg/dL
Ethanol140 mg/dL

During evaluation, the patient is initially cooperative but becomes increasingly aggressive and combative.  For safety reasons, he is given intravenous haloperidol and lorazepam.  Shortly afterward, the cardiac monitor displays the rhythm shown in the exhibit.  Which of the following most likely contributed to this patient's abnormal rhythm?
questionList.explanationText:
Causes of QT-interval prolongation

Acquired

  • Medications
    • Macrolides & fluoroquinolones
    • Antiemetics (eg, ondansetron)
    • Azoles (eg, fluconazole)
    • Antipsychotics, TCAs & SSRIs
    • Some opioids (eg, methadone, oxycodone)
    • Class Ia antiarrhythmics (eg, quinidine)
    • Class III antiarrhythmics (eg, dofetilide, sotalol)
  • Electrolyte abnormalities
    • ↓ Magnesium, ↓ potassium, ↓ calcium

Congenital

  • Romano-Ward syndrome (autosomal dominant)
  • Jervell & Lange-Nielsen syndrome (autosomal recessive)*

*Associated with sensorineural hearing loss.

SSRIs = selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors; TCAs = tricyclic antidepressants.

This patient with altered mental status (AMS) in the setting of alcohol use disorder (AUD) and likely nonadherence with schizophrenia medications developed cardiac arrhythmia shortly after receiving intravenous medications.  The cardiac rhythm shows torsade de pointes (TdP), suggesting excessive QT interval prolongation due to a medication adverse effect.

QT-interval prolongation is the ECG manifestation of delayed ventricular repolarization, which occurs due to impaired function of voltage-gated potassium channels.  Significantly delayed repolarization can trigger TdP, a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia that can lead to cardiac arrest.  Many medications, including some antipsychotic agents (eg, intravenous haloperidol), block the outward delayed rectifier potassium current to prolong the QT interval and increase the risk of TdP.

The risk of TdP is also increased with electrolyte derangements that prolong the QT interval (eg, hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia), which are common in patients with AUD due to poor nutrition.  When possible, patients receiving intravenous haloperidol or other QT-prolonging medications, particularly individuals at increased risk for arrhythmia, should undergo ECG testing prior to administration.  The medication must be withheld if the baseline-corrected QT interval is prolonged (eg, >450 msec).

Other medications administered intravenously for chemical restraint include lorazepam (a benzodiazepine) (Choice D) and diphenhydramine (an antihistamine); these drugs cause sedation but are not typically associated with significant QT prolongation and can be more safely used to sedate an agitated or combative patient until an ECG is obtained.  Many benzodiazepines are hepatically metabolized and should be administered with care due to the risk for respiratory depression.

(Choice A)  Although an elevated blood alcohol level causes CNS depression and sedation, it does not prolong the QT interval and does not increase the risk for TdP.

(Choice B)  An elevated blood ammonia level is often present in patients with decompensated cirrhosis (eg, distended abdomen suggesting ascites, edema suggesting hypoalbuminemia).  It may contribute to AMS (ie, hepatic encephalopathy) but does not increase the risk for TdP.

(Choice E)  AUD and poor nutrition may predispose to hypoglycemia, which should be excluded in patients with AMS.  However, hypoglycemia does not predispose to TdP.

(Choice F)  Significant hyponatremia can cause AMS, but it is not known to increase the risk of TdP.

Educational objective:
Antipsychotic agents (eg, haloperidol) can cause QT-interval prolongation; therefore, an ECG should be obtained prior to administering these agents to avoid causing a life-threatening arrhythmia (ie, torsade de pointes).
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Antipsychotics

questionMappingReferencesList.title: QTc prolongation by psychotropic drugs and the risk of torsade de pointes.
